content.webTitle: Rochdale: where every 200th person is an asylum seeker

fields.headline: Rochdale: where every 200th person is an asylum seeker
fields.bodyText: With its Victorian-era town hall, its high street full of chain coffee shops and its generous sprinkling of churches and mosques, Rochdale is in many senses an unremarkable northern market town. But demographically, Rochdale is unusual. For in this town north of Manchester, every 200th person is an asylum seeker. In asylum Britain, there is a rule: no town should have more than one asylum seeker for every 200 people. In Rochdale, the ratio is 0.99 per 200 - the most in England. For the local MP, Simon Danczuk, it is “far, far far too many”. In areas, particularly in the north of town, such as Smallbridge and Wardleworth, many of the houses and flats are home to a proportion of the 1,061 asylum seekers who have been sent by the Home Office to live in Rochdale. “I take the view that we should take in asylum seekers, that that’s the right and proper thing for a country like Britain to do,” says Danczuk. “But I think the dispersal system is wholly unfair. It’s skewed towards towns like Rochdale.” According to data published by the Guardian, the asylum dispersal scheme is heavily skewed towards poorer parts of the country. Rochdale ranks in the poorest 15% of the UK by median annual income. Some communities take more than 1,000 asylum seekers, whereas 174 local authorities – or 45% of all council areas – do not house any. The cost of housing asylum seekers and their £36.95 weekly allowance is met by the Home Office, and asylum seekers are not accommodated in council housing. But local authorities that house asylum seekers are not given any additional funding to help cover costs such as schooling and health services. This puts, says Danczuk, additional strain on places such as Rochdale that are already struggling. He says: “You can’t cut the funding to public services to towns and cities like Rochdale, like this government has done, and then expect us to take over 1,000 asylum seekers. It’s absolutely outrageous actually, I feel very strongly about it.” As do some of his constituents. “Well, you’ve come to the right place,” says Phil Malpas when asked about asylum seekers. Malpas, who runs a floor-laying business, is concerned about the number of asylum seekers in Rochdale and does not think Britain has a responsibility to help refugees. “No responsibility. Why should I pay money to someone who hasn’t given money to us?” he says. “[Immigrants] get everything given to them, everything for free; I don’t get anything. It just seems to me that the working class, working people, are being hit the hardest by immigration.” Nonetheless, at a nearby Red Cross drop-in centre, asylum seekers say they are grateful for the generosity Rochdale has shown them. Bakhtawer, an Iraqi Kurd, is full of praise for the town, which she says is full of “very good people who help us”. With tears in her eyes, she gestures to Margaret White, a volunteer who is teaching her and her daughter to knit. “Here, I am sad, I have no family, no mother, but she says, ‘don’t be sad’, she is my mother here.” But others are aware of an undercurrent of hostility. “A woman who fled Iran because of her faith said to me: ‘Sometimes my heart stops when I think people don’t like us,’” says Mark Coleman, the vicar at St Chad’s church, which runs a weekly welcome lunch. Debbie Callaghan, a volunteer, says there have been troubling incidents, though nothing akin to the recent attack on the 17-year-old asylum seeker Reker Ahmed in Croydon, south London. She points to a video shot by an asylum seeker from inside their flat, which shows people throwing eggs at their window from a park outside. “There’s still people that aren’t very nice in Rochdale,” says Callaghan. “The majority of us stand together, it’s the minority. We need to say we’re all welcome.” Callaghan says the way large parts of the community, particularly the Muslim community, have come together to support and welcome asylum seekers makes Rochdale “an example for the rest of the country”. She highlights the rooms full of clothing, prams, beds and furniture donated by individuals or collected from mosques. “Food, clothes, absolutely anything, I’d get it straight away. Whatever I asked for, I’d get it,” she says. “A lot of these families have benefited from the kindness of the Muslims of Rochdale. They’re amazing.” Tahir Mahmood, the chairman of the Rochdale Council of Mosques, acknowledges there is a feeling of solidarity because many asylum seekers come from Muslim-majority countries, but he is quick to dismiss the idea that this is the motivation for helping. “There is a feeling, but we don’t differentiate. There are Christians coming from Syria, it doesn’t matter who it is, we would help anybody. We’re all human beings – and we look at that first,” he says. Ann Alger, 71, is “Rochdale born and bred”. She says she does not know many asylum seekers, but thinks the government has a responsibility to help refugees. However, she is concerned about bringing more people to Rochdale when there are so few jobs and a feeling of general decline. “It’s a sad town now. Everything’s changed,” she says, sitting on a bench near the closed down market where she used to manage a tea shop. “I feel sorry for the young ones growing up here. “My friend was sick with cancer and this Pakistani woman came and brought food every day while she was sick, every day. That’s real community. To be polite I’ve learned a few words in Pakistani – ‘hello’, ‘how are you’. We should all do that and then we’d all get on better. If one street can mix, why can’t they all do it? It’d be a better country, this.”
